content: Write a sonnet about rivers in the style of William Wordsworth.

Upon the banks where ancient rivers flow,
Where Nature's hand hath carved with silent might,
I walk, and in their depths I seem to know
The very soul of Earth, so pure and bright.

These waters, born of mountains' crystal tears,
Descend in torrents, dance through valley glades,
Then, smoothing into tranquil, silver sheens,
They mirror skies that in their bosoms braid.

Oh, rivers! ye are life's own pulse and breath,
That courses through the veins of verdant lands;
Ye nourish all things, from the tiniest leaf
To forests vast, where ancient trees expand.

In you, I see the stream of time that flows,
Unending, ever-changing, yet the same.
